ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

FREE TRADE AGREEMENTS
(Benefits)


    1. Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) what kind of programmes does the Government plan to initiate in order to reap the benefits that will be derived from the recent successful Free Trade Agreements (FTAs) reached between Singapore and various countries; and (b) how can the recently retrenched employees from the banking sector be reskilled and trained to take up job opportunities arising from the successful FTAs.

    The Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker, Sir, our FTAs enhance Singapore's attractiveness to investors and strengthen our hub position in Asia. This is because the market access benefits and other preferential treatment that our FTAs carry will enhance the exports of companies in Singapore. Singapore companies and foreign

Column: 1488

investors will find it more attractive to invest in Singapore, thus generating more employment opportunities for Singaporeans.

    Our efforts to ensure that businesses are able to benefit from the FTAs begin well before negotiations are concluded. In the course of the negotiations, we actively seek feedback and suggestions from the private sector, in order to find out where the problems are. Armed with this information, we are able to negotiate a better agreement for companies. For the FTAs that are still under negotiation, we strongly encourage companies and business organisations like the Singapore Business Federation to play an even more active role in this process.

    Once an FTA is concluded, our focus turns to helping businesses understand the agreement so as to take advantage of them.

    First, we seek to reach out to the general business community through the media, the Internet and seminars. Such large-scale programmes allow us to create a general awareness of FTAs.

    Second, we recognise that a focused approach will be more effective in helping individual companies understand how they can directly benefit from the Agreements. Therefore, our economic agencies have also been in touch with Singapore-based companies to see how they can specifically leverage on FTA provisions to gain a greater competitive edge.

    Companies may not always want to reveal details on how they organise their operations to Government agencies. Instead, they may wish to tap on their legal or accounting advisors or other consultants to advise them on how to take advantage of the FTAs. We would therefore welcome efforts by the legal and accounting professions, as well as management consultants, to develop capabilities to be able to advise their clients on international trade and FTA issues.

    Ultimately, the extent to which Singapore benefits from these FTAs will

Column: 1489

depend on our people and businesses. Singapore businesses must seize the opportunities afforded by our FTAs to grow and expand internationally.

    At the same time, Singapore workers must be prepared to retrain and prepare themselves for the new job opportunities that will be created as a result of the FTAs. The FTAs will not help us to hold on to jobs that are no longer competitive, whether in the manufacturing or services sectors.

    Workers can take advantage of MOM's retraining schemes, such as the WorkSkills Training Programme (WSTP), the Self Employment Training Programme (SET), the Strategic Manpower Conversion Programme (SMCP) and the Skills Redevelopment Programme (SRP). Retrenched banking sector employees who are subsequently re-employed in the financial sector, can also take advantage of MAS' Financial Sector Development Fund Financial Training Scheme to upgrade their technical expertise.

    We encourage workers and unions to look to the new opportunities provided by the FTAs, and take advantage of the resources provided by the Government to prepare themselves well for these opportunities.

    Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast): Sir, can the Senior Minister of State kindly enlighten how we can actually explain this whole concept and programme of the FTAs to the man-in-the-street because, according to the Prime Minister's statement a few days back, about 20,000 jobs can be created arising from the FTAs and especially so in the manufacturing and service sectors? There are many people who are finding hope in this announcement and if more could be done to communicate and make it more simple to the man-in-the-street, it will help a lot.

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: I think that is a good point. We have been doing a fair bit to publicise the FTAs. First, of course, the full text of the FTAs as well as the business guides are all posted on the MTI's website. The economic agencies are organising seminars and business

Column: 1490

briefings. We have done seminars on our FTAs with New Zealand and Japan and we also did a fairly large-scale briefing of SMEs sometime in the middle of this year. This process will have to go on, not just to build general awareness but also to build specific awareness of opportunities involved in each FTA. Another approach will be to work with the unions so that they get a better awareness of the specific opportunities that the FTAs provide for workers in their sectors.

    Mr A. Nithiah Nandan (Nominated Member): Sir, I am very glad to hear that the Senior Minister of State will be briefing the unions. As a suggestion, maybe we could try ---

    Mr Speaker: Mr Nandan, you are supposed to ask questions.

    Mr Nithiah Nandan: All right. Will the Senior Minister of State consider having a dialogue session with the unions and also at the same time to work out specific programmes where the FTAs can positively benefit workers in general and where are the areas we need to identify to train them up?

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, this is a useful suggestion that MTI and Ministry of Manpower can look into together.

Column: 1490

RECESSION
(Assistance to companies)


    2. Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong asked the Minister for Trade and Industry in view of his statement that Singapore may slide into another recession, (a) how long and how deep will this coming recession be, and (b) what additional measures are being taken to help small and big Singapore companies to tide over this difficult period.

    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker, Sir, MTI's growth forecast for this year has been revised downwards to 2-2.5%. For next year, we are forecasting 2.0 - 5.0%, although there is considerable

Column: 1491

uncertainty because of the state of the global economy and the possibility of war in Iraq.

    Our growth forecast for this year reflects expectations of continued positive growth in the fourth quarter on a year-on-year basis, in other words, compared to the fourth quarter of last year. This is because our key exports markets are still growing, albeit more slowly. However, should GDP contract on a quarter-on-quarter basis in the fourth quarter, as happened in the third quarter, we will technically be in recession. We do not expect this to happen, but we cannot rule out the possibility.

    In an environment as uncertain as today's, there can be little certainty in short term economic forecasts. If US consumption does not fall sharply in the fourth quarter, and the major economies do not stumble badly, we should be able to achieve positive quarter-on-quarter growth in the fourth quarter and avoid a technical recession.

    Singapore's economic performance next year will also depend very much on how various external events pan out. We could see a good recovery in the economy in the second half of 2003 if the US has by then worked through the after-effects of the investment bubble of the late 1990s, and if confidence in the region around us is sustained.

    As mentioned in this House last month, several of the measures the Government implemented in July and October last year to help companies during this difficult period are still in place. These include JTC and HDB rental rebates, the cut in foreign workers' levy and concessions on port dues. We have also made enhancements to the Local Enterprise Technical Assistance Scheme (LETAS) and the Local Enterprise Finance Scheme (LEFS).

    We have also introduced other schemes aimed at helping SMEs. SPRING Singapore launched a Loan Insurance Scheme (LIS) in September 2002 to complement the Local Enterprise Financial Scheme

Column: 1492

(LEFS), and help SMEs get better access to financing. Unlike LEFS, which stipulates a fixed interest rate, LIS gives participating financial institutions the flexibility to decide on interest rates according to the risk profile of the borrower. This increases the chance of success of an SME's loan application. Private credit risk insurers insure 50 per cent of the loan against default. The Government co-shares the cost of the insurance premium with the SME.

    The Micro Loan Programme was also set up in November last year, to provide easier access to loans for very small enterprises to meet their working capital needs. Since its launch in November last year, almost 1,000 firms have benefited from this scheme with a total of $32 million in loans.

    Finally, the Government has also implemented reductions in corporate income taxes, and postponed the restoration of the CPF contribution rates. These will help all businesses during this difficult period.

    The Government is monitoring the economy closely. It is looking at whether some of the earlier economic relief measures need to be extended, and whether additional ways to help businesses and workers tide over the difficult period are necessary.

    Mr Tan Soo Khoon (East Coast): Mr Speaker, Sir, given the economic uncertainty and the fact that we have been told that there might be even a double-dip recession next year, would not the Government consider, as part of its strategy, a postponement of the proposed increase in the GST hike scheduled for January next year? Given the fact that the unemployment situation is set to increase further in the coming weeks or months, that people are already tightening their belts and will tighten their belts even further and therefore consumption spending will drop and businesses will suffer, and this would lead to a contraction in the economy in the months ahead, would he not consider such a move?

Column: 1493



    Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, a double-dip recession cannot be ruled out but it is not likely at this stage. There are some economists in the US who have painted a scenario of a double-dip in the US but the majority opinion remains that of positive growth in the US economy. Likewise for the region around us and the global economy. So we cannot rule it out but it is not a central scenario at this point, not something that we attach high likelihood to. We will have to watch the economy very carefully in the coming months and respond accordingly. Likewise, for unemployment. We are watching it very carefully but it is not a situation where we expect a sharp surge in unemployment figures at this point.

    The Prime Minister has mentioned publicly yesterday that the manner of implementation of the GST increase is being considered. This is being looked at together with various other economic relief measures, whether we should extend some of the earlier economic relief measures. This is being considered very carefully. There are obviously revenue implications. I should clarify that the existing plan, as it stood, was not a contractionary plan because the GST increase was accompanied by very substantial offset measures, including the Economic Restructuring Shares that would actually have meant a net boost in the amount of funds being put into the economy by the Government. It was actually, on balance, an expansionary package. But having said that, the Government is considering very carefully the mode of implementation of the GST increase, bearing in mind the economic difficulties of businesses and workers.

Column: 1493

HDB AND JTC COMMERCIAL PROPERTIES
(Rentals)


    3. Mr Charles Chong asked the Minister for National Development if his Ministry will consider extending the rental rebates and deferring the rental increases or the upward adjustments to 'market rental' of HDB and JTC commercial properties until the economic situation improves.

Column: 1494



    The Minister of State for National Development (Dr Vivian Balakrishnan) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, existing rental rebates provided by HDB to its commercial tenants will expire at the end of the year. The Government is currently reviewing these rebates taking into consideration the economic outlook.

    As for the upward adjustments to "market rental" of HDB commercial properties, HDB has already moderated their impact on its tenants by staggering the rental adjustments over four renewals at 3-yearly intervals since 1988 - a 12-year period. Tenants who are renewing their tenancies with rental increases from November 2001 onwards can further stagger their rental increase equally over a 3-year term.

    Mr Charles Chong (Pasir Ris-Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, could the Minister of State confirm when were these market rentals established? Was it before the recession or after the recession?

    Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the proposal to adjust rentals to the market is not a new one and, in fact, was negotiated back in 1988. The intention then was to ensure equity between shopkeepers who have heavily subsidised rentals versus the newer comers who were paying market rents. So this is not a new policy. Having said that, however, in view of the conditions, since November 2001, we have provided for a stagger within a stagger. And for those in their final term of adjustment, we stagger out the increases over three years.

    Mr Charles Chong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the Minister of State has not answered my question. My question was: when were these market rental rates established? Is it still current?

    Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: The market rental rates are decided by valuers and they will ensure that, at any point in time, the level at which it is set takes into

Column: 1495

account the current market conditions. And for those facing renewals from now onwards, the current market conditions are certainly taken into account.

Column: 1495

CODE ON RELIGIOUS HARMONY


    4. Ms Braema Mathiaparanam asked the Prime Minister (a) if he will clarify how the Code on Religious Harmony can be applied by Singaporeans; (b) from whom individuals can seek counsel when the Code is flouted; (c) what kind of remedial action can be taken when it is flouted; and (d) whether he will consider setting up a mediation council comprising different religious leaders to resolve conflicts arising from non-compliance with the Code on Religious Harmony.

    The Minister of State, Prime Minister's Office (Mr Chan Soo Sen) (for the Prime Minister): The proposed Code on Religious Harmony is meant to be a set of guiding principles on how Singaporeans should practise their religion when they interact with one another in our multi-racial, multi-religious, society. As Singapore has already achieved many years of religious harmony, I think the Code, when it is completed, will look rather familiar. However, it is still useful to remind ourselves of all these basic principles which have helped, and will continue to help, achieve and maintain religious harmony in Singapore.

    Therefore, the Code is actually a reflection of moral values and social norms. It is not a piece of legislation. Hence, there will be no penalties if the Code is flouted. If someone acts in such a manner as to violate religious harmony, there are existing mechanisms to deal with them, and it will not be dealt with by the Code.

    For example, under the Maintenance of Religious Harmony Act, the Minister for Home Affairs is empowered to issue restraining orders of up to a maximum of two years against persons inciting religious misunderstanding or causing inter-religious hostility. Any person who breaches the restraining order shall be

Column: 1496

guilty of an offence and be liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding $10,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years or to both. In the case of a second or subsequent offence, the person will be liable to a fine not exceeding $20,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding three years or to both. The Act also provides for the establishment of a Presidential Council for Religious Harmony. The Chairman and every member of the Council are appointed by the President on the advice of the Presidential Council for Minority Rights for a period of three years. The Council considers and reports to the Minister for Home Affairs on matters affecting the religious harmony in Singapore which are referred to the Council by the Minister or by Parliament.

    The Prime Minister has proposed a draft Code on Religious Harmony for discussion. And since I have been appointed to head the Working Group on the Code, I have been consulting with the national groups representing the various faiths in order to develop the Code, and this process will take place in the next few months. I will listen to and, as far as possible, incorporate all relevant views. The Code will be referred to the Presidential Council for Religious Harmony for consideration before it is finalised.

    Through the elaborate consultation process, I hope the finalised Code would be one that all major religions in Singapore can agree with and feel ownership for, and one that can be understood and internalised by Singaporeans.

    Mdm Ho Geok Choo: Sir, I would like to ask the Minister of State in what manner would this Code be practised. Is there a consideration to integrate it as part of the pledge-taking session, or are we going to have a separate session?

    Mr Chan Soo Sen: Mr Speaker, Sir, through the consultation process, we hope to achieve a situation whereby the various religious groups consider the Code as their

Column: 1497

Code, and not the Government's Code. And if the various religious groups consider the final Code as their Code, we can discuss in what manner they could remind their believers of this Code. I have actually exposed the preliminary idea to them that, for example, if all the religious groups agree, we can say that for the first week of every month, at the end of their weekly prayer, the Code can be read out to the devotees or followers just to remind the people. But all these are very, very preliminary at the moment. I maintain that what we want to achieve is for the various religious groups to consider the Code as their Code, and that they take it upon themselves to remind their believers and devotees of their Code.

    Mdm Ho Geok Choo: Based on what the Minister of State has just described, it will really take care of citizens with a religion. But in cases where they do not have a religion, they will not have a place of worship to practise such an oath-taking. So eventually when we have this objective of coming up with the Religious Harmony Code, how do we intend actually to cover the rest of Singaporeans who may not have a religion at this point?

    Mr Chan Soo Sen: I think it will depend on the content of the Code, whether it addresses everybody, or it addresses people who are practising a religion. If we are talking about addressing everybody, there is already a code which is in our National Pledge that all our students read every day where we pledge ourselves as one united people regardless of race, language or religion, and so on. But for those who are practising a religion, if the Code is to remind them that when they are practising a religion and when this goes into the common space, when they are interacting with people of different faiths, what is the understanding between our various religious groups on how we should handle that kind of situation. If the Code is to address that, then I would say it suffices to remind the people who are actively practising their religion.

    Mdm Ho Geok Choo: From what the Minister of State has just described, would he not think that it may lead to a lot of confusion in the sense that we are going to have two sets of Codes, one in the school and another set just basically for

Column: 1498

the religious groups? I do not know how this would develop eventually. Would he care to share some thoughts on this?

    Mr Chan Soo Sen: I do not know how it will develop eventually either. We are in the consultation process and we would like the various religious groups to play their part in formulating the Code and to play their part to remind their followers on the Code and how to internalise the Code. Since the process is still on-going, I cannot presuppose what would the turnout be at the end. But if we are talking about Singaporeans in general, my own view is that there is already a code called the National Pledge. But for those who are practising their religion actively and bearing in mind that Singapore is a multi-religious type of society, we want to practise a faith in such a way that it does not create misunderstanding or, worse still, create offence with each other. What I was saying is that if the Code addresses this situation, then to be able to remind the people who are actively practising their religion would have been well-served by this Code. And in addition, as Singaporeans, they also remember the National Pledge. So they are reminded twice.

    Ms Braema Mathiaparanam (Nominated Member): Could I ask the Minister of State about the question on mediation council? In the on-going process, is it possible that we do not have to use the Act and we can nip things in the bud?

    Mr Chan Soo Sen: This is a question that I will pose to the various religious groups that my colleagues and I are currently consulting. What we are doing is we are visiting group by group and we listen to their views on the Code itself as well as to listen to some feedback on the current state of religious harmony. After we have consulted all the groups, we will sit down and draft the Code before inviting everybody to sit and go through the Code together. Depending on what the Code looks like then, we would be able to raise this question of mediation council with them and to see whether they feel good enough to actually form their own mediation councils so that, for minor

Column: 1499

matters, there is no need to make use of the Maintenance of Religious Harmony Act.

SELF-HELP GROUPS
(Review of model)


    5. Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Acting Minister for Community Development and Sports, after September 11 and the recent development of Jemaah Islamiyah (JI) activities, (a) are there plans to (i) review the model of self-help groups and (ii) enhance the concept of cohesiveness by amalgamating them under one umbrella body without disrupting their individuality at the same time; and (b) what more can be done and how can we ensure that there is more collaboration of resources among these self-help groups.

    The Acting Minister for Community Development and Sports (Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim): Sir, September 11 and the arrests of the Jemaah Islamiyah members reinforce the need for a concerted effort to build harmony and trust among Singaporeans. But they have nothing to do with the self-help groups' role in Singapore.

    The self-help groups were set up to help the underachievers in their community to level up. While national programmes and CDCs can cater to most Singaporeans, the self-help groups are more effective in reaching out to the last 5% that need help, given their cultural affinity, language and networks. Moreover, different communities have different priorities to address. A community self-help approach allows each community to focus on the issues and problems that are most pressing for that community. The existence of self-help groups should not be perceived as a weakness but as complementary to our multi-racial approach. Importance of protecting payment and settlement systems from disruptions

Any netting arrangements in the payment and settlement systems should likewise be enforceable. If we take the second approach, in other words, the IP approach, will we generate a sense of disenchantment among our young who are not in the IP programme, that the system is stacked against them if nature does not endow them with the genes to do well in our system? How do we deal with the frustrations that

Column: 1575

come with the realisation that determination, discipline and other human qualities come second, while natural endowment becomes most important? How do we address the rootedness of Singaporeans when some of us are dealt with a lousy deck of cards, and the Government reinforces this in our education system?

    Frankly speaking, Sir, I am torn between these two poles. In my mind, I think IP is necessary and appropriate, and would bring great benefit to the students in the stream. In my heart, I feel that this will intensify the angst and stress in our education system and make for perhaps a less harmonious society. In view of the Singapore economy which will be very dependent on the creativity of our people, my mind is winning this tug of war but my heart wishes that it need not be so. Nonetheless, I would urge the Ministry to be cognisant of this when implementing the IP. This should give the assurance that the non-IP students will continue to get the attention and the resources allocated to them currently. I am glad to note that the Minister is cognisant of this and has already reassured us in his speech.

    Sir, both of these concepts look good on paper. Whether they will bring the benefits we envisage will depend on the implementation. There are many issues of implementation - and there are 31 speakers after me. The key one, in my mind, is the preparedness of the teachers by 2006. The question is: will these few years be sufficient to get the system ready? I believe that in implementing the IP, only a number of schools will be involved initially. I understand that this number is less than the number of schools currently offering the GEP. So, do we also admit non-GEP students into IP? What would happen to the GEP students in schools that are not implementing the IP? How do we deal with the aspirations of the GEP students in these schools if they could not be transferred to the IP?

    There are also other recommendations in the White Paper, such as the establishment of private schools and the

Column: 1576

ability of some schools to offer other academic programmes such as the IB. These are meant to bring out greater diversity in the education system to meet the specific needs of the student population.

    Sir, I believe it is reasonable to experiment with the concept of private secondary schools. In this respect, I am glad that MOE has insisted that these schools must meet the minimum criteria of 50% Singaporean students in the population and must comply with the National Education guidelines. I have no great issue with the private schools, except that we must address the concern of the public about the exclusiveness of such schools. Already, there are public comments about our students not interacting enough between those of different ethnic backgrounds. We need to ensure that such independent schools do not become institutes where only the sons and daughters of the rich and the famous intermingle and build networks for the future.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the recommendations of the White Paper will bring about fundamental and significant changes in our education system. I would like to thank Senior Minister of State Tharman for steering his Review Committee to come out with these comprehensive and well-considered policy recommendations and to thank the Minister for accepting these recommendations. These changes will affect every Singaporean. For some, the change will be beneficial. For others, it will bring about greater anxiety and stress. To me, what is important is that the motivation of the MOE is a positive one, and I am glad to hear that the Ministry is prepared to do what is necessary to ensure that the new initiatives would succeed.

    Sir, we need to break through the present mindset and to bring the education system in Singapore to the next higher level of performance. I support the changes but urge caution and continuous monitoring to remedy any negative impact.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan: Mr Speaker, I am delighted that far-reaching changes

Column: 1577

are now being proposed to the system of JC/Upper Secondary School education. The present system has not had a major revamp for 30 years. Like so much of Singapore Inc., it is highly efficient and accomplishes a great deal with minimum fuss. But the accompanying litany of complaints is long and familiar. And my fellow Parliamentary colleagues before me have given details of some of these.

    Students and parents bemoan the undue stress the system has imposed from intense rote learning and the cookie cutter approach. Significantly, by agreeing to the reduction in the number of hours per 'A' level subject, the MOE seems to implicitly admit that the present system, by international comparison, over teachers in terms of content and subject hours, is generating an enormously stressful learning experience.

    University educators and employers find our students wanting, because they are adept at knowledge acquisition but not knowledge application or creation. They often bemoan the failure of the system to inculcate critical thinking and communication skills. It is well known that Singaporean students are reticent and poor communicators in comparison with foreign counterparts. These anecdotal observations have thus far not been negated by statistics that many Government departments are fond of using to demolish arguments.

    Indeed, they are reinforced by a recent study by the Ministry of Trade and Industry which shows clearly that, compared to the advanced economies, Singapore is pretty strong in acquiring knowledge, but is less so in creating, disseminating or applying information. The report further notes that it is in knowledge application where Singapore lags furthest behind and here, the weakest link is entrepreneurship.

    Sir, please let me state categorically at the outset that I do see the value of a rigorous education system that stretches students, and stress per se is indeed no reason to relax the rigour of the JC/Upper Secondary education system. The estimated 25% of each year's cohort that

Column: 1578

enter Upper Secondary/JC, one can safely assume, represent the best of the crop and nothing beats a good solid education to prepare them for either a university education or alternative learning pathways to a useful career.

    Without any question, the changes taking place all around us call for new responses. We urgently need to build up a pool of trained manpower with the skills and the aptitude to tackle the economic challenges of a highly competitive globalised, knowledge and innovation-driven economy.

    Amongst the tirade of recommendations made by the ERC sub-committees, the need to revamp our education system to foster entrepreneurship stands out very strongly as a common and central recommendation. In fact, one of the strongest advocates comes from the Sub-committee on Enhancing Human Capital, chaired by the Minister of State for Manpower and Education, Dr Ng Eng Hen, himself.

    Indeed, Minister of State Ng Eng Hen's recent ERC sub-committee report begins where the White Paper also begins - the pressing need to inject more flexibility and diversity into our education system. The goal is to enable the system to perform optimally its equipping task, and make our schools, to use the ERC report's memorable words, "creators of knowledge, engines of innovation and cradles of enterprise."

    In a nutshell, there are, I believe, three underlying core principles enunciated in the review:

    1. greater breadth - with focus on thinking and higher order skills, not just academic or subject content;

    2. greater flexibility - to accommodate preference for different types and depth of subjects; and

    3. greater diversity - to allow different pathways of education to accommodate different types of students.

    Sir, I support these broad principles and aims enunciated. But in my assessment,

Column: 1579

they have still not been applied widely or rigorously enough to the vision for a new education landscape. In what follows, I will explain my reasons by highlighting five major concerns arising from the review.

    My first concern relates to execution. While the principles are sound, the execution can and should take on different hues. Thus, a key concern would be in the manner of implementation of the recommendations. For instance, how can existing teachers, who are themselves products of an era where education is largely knowledge acquisition, as well as new teachers, be equipped to help students develop conceptual thinking, knowledge process skills, independent thinking and communication skills?

    What are the changes that must be made to the recruitment of new teachers and their training? How should the syllabus, teaching and assessment methods be shaped to ensure they achieve the aims of the review? What needs to be done for existing and often older teachers to help them grasp the issues?

    The Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry and Education, Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam, who chairs the Review Committee, himself had acknowledged that the success of the revised curriculum hinges on how it is executed, particularly in the curriculum design and the training of teachers. As they say, the devil is in the details.

    The most enlightened and exquisite curriculum or programme is only as good as the way it is implemented. Here, I quote the editorial of the Straits Times of 16th November 2002:

    'Where the education system is concerned, it is not just a matter of rearranging chairs, building new schools, but changing the insides of people, including the people tasked with making the changes. Who will teach the teachers?'

    Indeed, from the feedback I have received, I suspect that there is little disagreement among Singaporeans about the noble intentions of the changes, but

Column: 1580

the "How" will need to be carefully crafted and conveyed to all stakeholders.

    I would like to suggest that MOE involve educators and other relevant stakeholders in the design of the new curriculum and make the process more transparent to parents and students. Before actual implementation of the revised curriculum, MOE should widely expose these for comments by the stakeholders so that any kinks can be ironed out before implementation. MOE, in accepting this report by the Review Committee, should also follow up with a subsequent report regarding how the curriculum has been revised and trimmed, additional new teaching and assessment methods that need to be adopted to achieve the aims of the report. This could be presented to the public and Parliament for feedback. And at this juncture I would like to thank the Minister for noting that some of these would be done.

    My second concern relates to the need to take at least one contrasting subject and implications on workload. I fully subscribe to the logic of having a contrasting subject, so as to expose students to subjects outside their core content knowledge, and help them think in inter-disciplinary terms. Increasingly, complex problems we are facing call for multi-dimensional responses that a broad-based education can elicit.

    Again, the execution of this could leave much to be desired. Specifically, except for perhaps a handful of students, the majority do not possess the aptitude to be more or less competent in every subject. Most students have preferences and aptitude for one category of subjects - eg, science or arts. To accommodate a broader based enhanced curriculum, the Review Committee has proposed trimming curriculum content and time of each subject.

    However, even though the number of hours per subject is reduced, the need for a contrasting subject brings the total tally for a typical "A" level student to a minimum of 7 subjects, up from the existing minimum of 5.

Column: 1581



    This may mean greater stress as students are taxed beyond the comfort zone of the subjects around the core areas that they prefer. The aim of broadening students' horizon beyond the academic would be defeated if they have to struggle unduly in their contrasting subject, leaving them with precious little time for anything else. In fact, whilst there would be a 10% reduction in overall curriculum time under the proposed system, for existing triple Science students doing 4 "A" levels, the overall curriculum time for Humanities students doing 3 "A" levels will remain unchanged at about 1,300 hours. This means that the weaker students in the cohort may be unduly stretched as they now have to take more subjects and on top of this, at least one subject outside their specialisation in the same overall curriculum time.

    Additionally, the typical "kiasu" Singaporean parents would want their children to do well in all subjects, as long as the subject contributes to the admission criteria of our local universities. Hence, additional pressure may also emanate from this source. Once again, the recommendations could falter at the execution stage.

    To alleviate this problem, it must be ensured that the reduced hours genuinely reflect correspondingly reduced content, that does not somehow creep back into the system by way of after-class teaching.

    My third major concern relates to the through-train education.

    Sir, I support the proposals to have through-train to accelerate the learning pace and offer the brighter students time to pursue their interests and enrich their own educational experience without having their attention diverted by two major examinations.

    As only the brightest crop of students - the top 10% - will be permitted to participate, the risk of these students being left without completing at least the "O" levels should they fail the through-train will be remote. In some ways, the through-train is thus another version of the GEP, and yet another form of streaming. I know of

Column: 1582

many parents who desire that their children be able to enter the GEP. Additionally, the perception is that the best resources are also devoted to grooming these students, perhaps more so on a per capita basis than the rest of the crop. The fact that this programme and its successor, the through-train, falls within the national school system raises the prospect that this is like officially sanctioned Darwinism at work.

    Sir, I fully accept that we are all made differently and abilities likewise vary. I also subscribe to the idea that bright students with exceptional aptitude are better off developing other skills and pursuing non-curriculum-related work for character and leadership honing than taking two major examinations. But I would like MOE to consider steps to ensure that the creme de la creme of Singapore's student population entering the through-train programme do not develop isolationist tendencies, but integrate into the mainstream and not look down at their lesser brethren.

    It is comforting to note that schools and JCs planning to run the integrated programme will set aside or offer additional places to ensure that students from non-affiliated schools are not shut out of the JC. These secondary schools would also continue to offer the standard "O" level track which would allow students to stay on the traditional route, if they are assessed to be unable to make the mark, say, at secondary 2.

    Since 1990, the percentage of P1 cohort who passed "A" levels has been above 20%. Hence, I would like to urge the Ministry to monitor the progress and performance of the through-train cohort with the view of eventually making it accessible to a higher percentage of students, from the targeted 10%, who can benefit from the system.

    My fourth concern relates to the setting up of private schools. The Review Committee recommends adding a few privately-run and funded secondary schools and JCs. Such schools are to add diversity and choice in education as well

Column: 1583

as to provide an added source of ideas and innovative practices in education.

    The Committee acknowledges that such a move would however introduce some degree of elitism into the national education system, since admission would depend in part on ability to pay. Nonetheless, the need for a more varied education landscape is becoming inevitable in the face of globalisation and an increasingly mobile and informed citizenry that demands choice. Privately-funded schools are likely to appeal to a minority of parents who are at odds with the national school system and believe that their children could fit better in a less rigid alternative system. Private schools can provide greater variety and choice of alternative school systems, which can meet the needs of such families, and perhaps help stem the outflow of Singaporeans arising from unhappiness with the education system.

    As one Douglas Koh quipped, in response to the Review Committee's proposals, "For years I have been thinking of emigrating because of the lack of alternative school systems. Now I may be spoilt for choice."

    More importantly, privately-funded schools can cater to the children of returning Singaporean expatriates who may prefer an alternative curriculum which they are more familiar with or prepared for.

    Sir, I therefore support this proposal and in fact would like to urge MOE to allow private schools to be open for all levels instead of confining this to Secondary and JC levels so that the diversity in choice can be complete.

    My final key concern relates to widening the benefits, downwards and upwards. Firstly, widening the benefits downwards. The recommendations in the White Paper would benefit the most able of each cohort. For instance, the JC review would benefit the top 25% of the cohort, whilst the proposed through-train system is aimed at the top 10%. But what about the

Column: 1584

other 75% of the cohort? What about those further upstream in the lower secondary and primary schools? Should not the new education roadmap of greater breadth, greater flexibility and greater diversity be also made available to them so that all will be using the same map to navigate effectively together?

    The benefits of diversity, flexibility and choice in education and the nurturing of a thinking culture should spread to the rest of the cohort so that the less able will at least receive some preparation to equip them for the challenges of the KBE. For surely the goal is not merely to have a thinking elite, but also a thinking nation. We need thinkers at all levels of society and not just at the top, and to level up the weak, without dumping down the strong. The White Paper has allowed for greater customisation or streaming with concomitant diversity and choice at the top end of the cohort with the through-train and specialised school proposals. Greater diversity, choice and customisation should also be accorded to the rest of the cohort and in this respect, I support the following ERC Human Capital Sub-committee's recommendations:

    Firstly, to allow secondary students to have wider access to subjects beyond their particular stream. For instance, students in "N" level could take a few subjects where they are strong in at "O" level.

    Secondly, to allow selected students a longer period to complete their examinations by taking fewer subjects in more sittings, so that they can pursue external interests such as sports and the arts, which they excel in.

    These would then reduce some of the rigidity in the system, which though efficient, may hamper late developers. In fact, the answer to the much-maligned streaming system could thus paradoxically lie in more streaming or greater customisation of learning, particularly for the exceptional, the wayward and the just different.

    There is obviously a great deal of administrative clumsiness, and some loss of efficiency may have to be initially

Column: 1585

tolerated but fundamentally - allowing even more diversity should - in this regard be seen as part of the maturation process in our education system. The MOE, by accepting the White Paper, is already allowing some "messiness" to creep into the currently highly efficient system.

    Secondly, widening the benefits upwards. There is also the need to start grounding critical thinking skills from the echelons of lower secondary and even primary school, so that they will not start on the wrong footing. Again, as noted by the Human Capital ERC Sub-committee, we need to inculcate new traits such as thinking and communication skills early in the education process.

    Referring to tertiary students, I remember coming across a T-shirt worn by an undergraduate that had the words "I is a university student." There is some reality behind this tongue-in-cheek humour.

    As an ex-University lecturer, I can testify to the poor command of English, a significant number of undergraduates suffer from, as a consequence of inadequate grounding during their primary and secondary school days.

    One cannot go far back enough, as psychologists will tell you, habits of the mind are formed at a very young age. This laying of foundation is especially crucial for the dysfunctional families where the home environment may not be conducive for learning and school is the only avenue for learning.

    MOE announced the "Thinking Schools, Learning Nation" initiative in 1997 and curriculum content was trimmed by up to 30% in 1999. However, by all accounts, and as noted earlier, students and parents continue to remain stressed by the workload, leaving students with very little time for critical thinking and analysis.

    The MOE should thus also review the curriculum content and workload of students in the primary and secondary schools to see if content can be further trimmed just like in the case of the JCs.

Column: 1586



    The White Paper notes that the current academic curriculum load in JCs is heavy compared to foreign education systems like the "A" levels in the UK and the IB. This is despite the fact that the curriculum was trimmed in 1999. By the same token, we may still be overloading and over-teaching our primary and secondary students. This, I submit, could place incoming upper secondary/JC students on the wrong footing and diminish the gains they could make from the very revisions we are now debating in this House.

    As the saying goes, we are the product of what we eat and this is true, whether it is food for the stomach or fodder for the brain.

    Arguably, our education system is superior to those in many countries, and has largely met the needs of our economy and citizens. However, with the rapid pace of globalisation, there is growing evidence that the system, as it stands, would not be able to meet the needs of the future workplace and economy.

    As Prof Edison Liu, Head of the Singapore Genomic Programme notes, "Yes, the Singapore education system is good. Yes, it is considered among the best in the world in mathematics and the sciences. But the question is not what Singapore needs now, but what the country will need 10 years from now."

    To enable us to compete effectively in the global economic arena, we need creative and critically thinking workers, not compliant workers. International Survey Research recently reported that based on its employee surveys, Singapore's chief executives tend to be good stewards rather than leaders. This is corroborated by a recent conversation I had with a PR from China who runs trading companies in Singapore and China. He told me he spends more time in China than Singapore, not because his family is in China - his family is in fact in Australia - but because he knows that the Singaporean manager can be trusted to run his company according to his instructions. He says that if he were to leave his China office unattended for too long, he fears one of his employees may set up a

Column: 1587

rival firm, just across the road, to compete against him. He remarked that Singaporean managers are very competent and compliant. Ethics aside, Chinese managers are also very competent, but they are also always looking at ways to be their own boss.

    I suspect that our famously rigid education system has no small part to play in shaping the current mindset of Singaporeans. In order to reform our education landscape to produce creative workers, innovators and entrepreneurs, there needs to be a mindset change for all - students, parents, teachers and the MOE. It is heartening that the MOE has accepted the Review Committee's recommendation to reform the JC/Upper Secondary system to better prepare students for the unpredictable future.

    Changing the curriculum to allow for more broad-based education and nurturing thinking skills for JC and bright upper secondary school students as well as giving them more options are first steps in the right direction. But the system would also have to be changed upstream and for the rest of the cohort in order to allow all and sundry - the exceptional, the normal, the wayward and the just different - to have a chance to survive and prosper. Until this is done, the Sim Wong Hoos and, if I may add, the Olivia Lums would continue to remain elusive.

    I therefore urge MOE not to delay but look into the equally needed reforms for those upstream and the remaining cohort outside the ambit of the upper secondary/JC system. This is a call not only by the public but by many from the ERC Sub-committees. I am sure that, with determination, MOE would be able to marshall resources to look at these areas simultaneously, as it is looking into the implementation of the changes for the JC/upper secondary system.

    Indeed, it is very comforting to note a recent example of MOE's eagerness to act decisively. Proof of this is in the recent change in the choice of secondary school available to pupils after their PSLE results,

Column: 1588

instead of before. Additionally, MOE has also now agreed to a single JC intake. As one principal remarked, this single intake of JC has been fed to MOE for more than 10 years and had remained unchanged. With MOE's new added willingness to change, as seen in the acceptance of the Review Committee's Report, I have high hopes (and I hope I would not be proven wrong) that MOE would seriously consider and implement many of the other proposed and much needed changes in the education system.

    With this, Sir, I support the motion.

    The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee): Mr Speaker, Sir, parents and some MPs in this House have been highly critical of our education policies. This is not at all surprising considering the importance Asians place on education. Unfortunately, some of us, indeed many of us, have a tendency to claim credit for our children's success and blame the system for their failure. But children do not fail until we think they have.

    Clearly in any society, there are slow learners, there are fast learners. Education, Sir, is not a race. Education is a journey, and not a destination. Yes, there are intermediate stops along the way - PSLE, 'O' levels, 'N' levels, and so on, and so forth. It does not really matter whether a child takes a slightly different, if longer, route to reach his own objective, his own destination.

    Education, Sir, is not about how fast we reach our own destiny, but how far we can do so. MOE, in the last decade or so, has become a convenient punching bag for society's distorted definition of success. Really, a lot of the noise we hear in this House and the media do not do justice to our system here. They are both unfair and without basis.

    Our system is not perfect. I think there are defects. But the system is not broken. The way we hear it in this House is that it

Column: 1589

is almost broken. But I say that the system is not broken and this is saying plenty about our system versus the systems elsewhere. Dr Wang mentioned the standards in the States and Britain. I will come back to that a bit later on.

    Many countries, including the States and Britain, are revamping their systems because scholastic standards have fallen to disastrously low levels. Here, we are fixing a problem that does not exist. It is a successful problem. Our students do well. There are lots of As in the 'A' levels and we say that there is something wrong in that system. Here, the MOE is revamping the JC and upper secondary school system for quite a different reason from that now going on in the States, in Britain and in Japan.

    Under the new system, many parents have the perception that the system is going to be easy on their children. There is hope that more students in Singapore under the new system will be better off. I think they will be. But there will also be a lot of heartaches. Because under the new system, there is a higher degree of differentiation, as Dr Amy Khor mentioned. It is in a way another level of streaming, if you put the students through a through-train system, if the students went into the specialised school of Mathematics and Science (something which I will talk about a bit later on). MPs and educators cannot be oblivious to the events around the world. And we seem to be very focused about the system in Singapore when we talk about the problem. We all know the problems. But if you look around elsewhere, the problems we have, the problems we face, are not serious.

    Only two years ago at the 2000 Presidential election campaign in the States, education was what Americans called a "hot button issue", in other words, something so hot, it would decide who would be the next President. Why? Because an employers' survey showed that two-thirds, that means, more than 60% of high school graduates (we call it 'A' levels, they call it high school) did not have the skills necessary to succeed in the workplace. Indeed, Americans have decried, debating

Column: 1590

the declining standards in schools for over two decades. So has Britain, so has Japan. And on balance, I think we have done well.

    The media, the press and academics should know better. How do we know we have done well? I think the best test is to benchmark our system versus systems elsewhere. And I think the best objective benchmarking is the International Mathematics and Science test which is culturally neutral. It does not depend on the person's language or his upbringing, and the system is totally objective. The sample sizes are large enough. The number of countries participating is representative enough. But therein lies the problem. Parents cite competition and, here, we have heard two speakers before me saying competition is a major fault of our education system. I think in particular, parents and many of us here are against ranking because they think that ranking engenders a culture of what we call "destructive competition". The real reason, if we touch our hearts, is not competition or ranking, but the fear and disappointment that our sons and daughters do not get into a ranked school. I think that is the heart of the problem.

    If all of us want to send our sons and daughters to schools that can only take in 10% of every cohort, then by definition 90% of the parents of that cohort will be disappointed. But is this necessary? The hysteria about not getting into a ranked school like RI, RGS, Chinese High, is totally irrational. All our secondary schools are not bad. It is just that, if you have a spread of a few hundred schools, there must be some better schools and some not so good schools. But the real test is if a student that does not get into a ranked school, does he measure up to international scholastic benchmarks? If he does, I think it is not a problem. If he does not, then there is a problem.

    Please remember, as Dr Wang correctly pointed out, that our students are held in high esteem when they go to British or American universities, many of them get exemption. Every student here does well in very good universities anywhere in the world. It will of course make parents

Column: 1591

happy, if MOE does not rank schools. But I think that would be a retrograde step. Competition and ranking, using examination results, are part of the education landscape everywhere. I think Singapore is a late starter.

    Here, critics equate ranking using examination results as destructive competition. But, elsewhere, they have changed euphemism. They call examinations accountability. You might ask: accountability to whom? To taxpayers who fund public schools, or to parents who want to know which private schools are good so that they can spend a lot of money to send their children to these schools.

    All around the developed world, there is an urgency to get scholastic achievements up. In Chicago, you read not long ago in the Straits Times, the authority is giving away cash grants of US$10,000 to schools which improve on their grades. Some schools in Texas are cutting down on play time and recess time to focus on core examinable skills. In Japan, educationists have found that years of education that give children room to grow, what Japanese call "the zest of life", in the last 12 years have left a serious gap.

    I have just distributed a paper which, according to the opinion of four Japanese scholars in Tokyo University, is called "The Truth About Declining Scholastic Achievement", a long paper, but just read the introduction and the conclusion and you will know the message. There is a simple Mathematics test inside here and you are expected to score 90 marks. The conclusion of these four Japanese scholars is that 12 years ago, they did a survey, they found that the students, like our students today, spent a lot of time studying. They got good grades, but the parents were not happy. So the Ministry of Education then changed the system towards the American system, more broad-based, more electives and the results had not been welcomed at least by these four scholars. Their argument is that basic Mathematics scores had fallen by up to 10 points. Where students used to

Column: 1592

get 70-80 marks for the test shown inside here, today they are getting 50-60 marks. Their argument is that standards had fallen.

    I go on to America which many of you have more knowledge. Now, after years of laissez-faire and falling academic standards, the state of Massachusetts has mandated that all public high school graduates must pass, what they now call, the Massachusetts Comprehensive Assessment System in order to get a High School Diploma. Before that, there was no examination. Every school graduate, they take the SAT, then they go to university. But now, in the state of Massachusetts, they want a standardised testing on core subjects.

    Nature abhors a vacuum. If Singapore Government does not rank schools, somebody or some organisation would, because the public is hungry for information. In Singapore, the Ministry of Education ranks schools. In the state of Massachusetts, they do not rank schools. But they publish the results obtained by the students in different schools. And what happens? The local media fixes up these results, does the analysis and publishes a ranking list. The Financial Times publishes an education supplement every year, ranking all the schools in Britain, sometime around August/September before the term starts. It is a special pull-out, by the way.

    In Singapore, although MOE ranks schools, it does not publish detailed results - RI gets how many As in History, how many As in Mathematics. In the state of Victoria, you might be surprised, and in many states in Australia, detailed subject results are published - Melbourne High get so many As in Mathematics, so many Bs in Science. Although they did not rank schools, one look at the results you will know which is the best school, which is the not-so-good school. So ranking is universal by different names, if you like. And we should keep ranking and competition in its proper perspective. The competition we face in Singapore is not internal, but really external. By that, I mean it is not competition between an

Column: 1593

RI boy and a Chinese High and an ACS boy, or between RJC and Hwa Chong and ACJC. Sure, we want them to have some friendly competition so that they have sparring partners and benchmark each other. But the real competition is between us and foreign systems. It is only when the entire local system is levelled up and superior to a foreign system that we collectively stand a chance of making ourselves relevant in the brave new world, in the new economy. To put it bluntly, collectively, are we better off than our neighbours? Collectively, are we better off than the world?     Parents also take issue with the unforgiving and elitist system which streams students according to their learning abilities. We have heard a lot in this House. We have to persevere or we would not have a continuous stream of badminton, bowling, ping-pong, playwrights and violinist stars to stand proud for us. We redefine what is success for our young.

    I believe that the key to the success of the proposed new system rests on two points revolving around implementation. One, to ensure that there is an adequate pool of teachers who can switch from the traditional approach to teaching. No longer must there be just one way or a fixed way to approach a problem. Students' curiosity must be aroused, and they must be guided to figure out complex issues with their own thinking and insights.

    Encouragement must abound. Remove the fear of failure, of giving wrong answers. At all ages, students must be encouraged to experiment, to fail, understand why they failed, nudged to pick up and try again. Teachers must establish that rapport with the students, create an intellectually uninhibited environment in the classroom; unfreeze the students psychologically from the paralysis that stems from the fear of "messing up".

    My second point on implementation is priority and pace. I believe the approach is correct. We must not fail because we do not apply the adequate level and type of resources in the execution. Hence, while

Column: 1612

the changes proposed are bold, we may have to prioritise.

    The proposal of creating even greater diversity in courses and new pathways is, in my opinion, not an area of immediate urgency. We must allow time for the students to reorientate to these new educational skills and priorities. Introducing too many changes all at the same time may, in fact, cause saturation, heavy workload, and may result in disruption and confusion for both students and teachers. A phased approach will be a better way to introduce such evolutions.

    The proposal is comprehensive in many aspects. However, I hope the Committee would consider three more factors.

    Firstly, it is a system that is unforgiving; one that does not allow repeated failures. The flexibility and diversity of the new proposal involve some form of risk taking by the students too. They are making decisions at a tender age and we must be prepared that some make mistakes in judgement. Here is the only area where I think the proposal has not gone far enough. We must have a structure in which they are given a second chance; and even maybe a third. For if we subscribe to life-long learning, then we must allow students to unwind earlier choices and start anew. Like what the Senior Parliamentary Secretary said, "as long as the train arrives, it does not matter if it is late." So along the way, maybe we may create the entrepreneurial environment that we all yearn for.

    My next point is that the new proposal should increase emphasis on National Education. This has been introduced in schools and it must continue to be emphasised. I have heard from a fellow MP that he detects that younger people in the upper secondary and post-secondary exhibit less of an identification to Singapore than those in their mid-twenties.

    Why is this so? Should not this sense of identity set in earlier rather than later? Hence, I hope that the Committee will look into more aspects of National Education. Beyond textbooks, bring National Education to life, eg, visits to military

Column: 1613

camps, exposure to our war heroes, our journey to water sufficiency, etc.

    We are a young nation; our people are always looking ahead and perhaps spending too little time remembering the past. We must do more to commemorate and celebrate the sacrifices of those that had made nationhood possible for us. The achievements, sacrifices and contributions of the many notable Singaporeans must be made known to the young. Hence, why not make National Education one of the KI or PW topics? Rather than suffer the fate that, if imposed upon, some youngsters feel they are being brain-washed; let them go on a journey of self-discovery.

    My third point concerns stress and pressure. This comes up often whenever the subject of education in Singapore is discussed. Could the Committee consider more emphasis on continual assessment and reduce the frequency of examinations? With less rote learning, there should be a correspondingly less need for examinations that we know today. Learning should be fun. The KI approach could be extended to even more subjects. Examination pressure may actually paradoxically be mitigated by incessant and continuous assessments. And, through life, we are continually assessed.

    Beyond my earlier suggestions on some adjustments to the proposals, I am totally supportive. Especially, in the new school environment, emphasis must be on students presenting and convincing other students. Communication skills must be brought to the forefront. From a tender age, they must learn to stand up, speak, be heard, convince and defend.

    I have just returned from a short trip to Israel and one thing I heard is that when you put two Israelis together you will get three opinions. Why not?

    As we hope to turn out generations of more inquiring Singaporeans, we may also have to handle the possibility of a more chaotic, challenging, vibrant and unpredictable environment. But this is exactly the strength of a pluralistic society, tapping the wisdom and experience of

Column: 1614

everyone. We just have to be prepared for this new environment, stay the course and not waver in our resolve, for it could get uncomfortable for the older people used to more compliance. It is a journey that we must see through.

    In conclusion, I reiterate that I am in favour of the proposal to revise the education system. In the process, we must bear in mind not to put additional pressure on our students.     While aiming for a more flexible curriculum and to develop thinking generations of Singaporeans, the stress factor must not be increased. The new system should allow for students to learn at their pace, provide for those who may be late developers and for those with non-academic talents.     We want multi-faceted Singaporeans who will contribute to the economy and add vibrancy to our young nation. We want thinkers, creators, sportsmen and artists. Is it a tall order? Perhaps, but we are a nation known not to wallow in discussion, one that is quick on our feet. We act on solving our issues and that is what we are doing right now.

    Being examination savvy is no longer enough. Our young must be equipped with the best hi-tech fishing rods, nets and spear-guns to go fishing and not merely provided with fishes. Column: 1615

all, I would like to thank you for this opportunity to join in the debate on this motion. There are 27 other colleagues who would like to speak on the motion and I will try my best to make my speech short and brief.

Can MOE consider granting some sort of "Certificate of Standard" for these students so that they would have at least a certificate to show that they have progressed over the years in this "through-train", and has been exempted from the "O" level examinations? Column: 1617

assess the potential of the students, and to customise the teaching accordingly, so that the students would derive the optimal benefits from the system. I think the teachers will play a very important part. I would like to know whether we have enough teachers who are adequately equipped to take on this higher responsibility. Let me give you an illustration. Teaching is like cooking. If you have some high-quality abalone, but you do not have a good chef to cook it, you would not be able to serve out a delicious abalone dish. The students were invited to ask questions, and many questions were asked by the young children. It was indeed a highly interactive session. Column: 1618

of exercise. This is what I call creative teaching!

    Thirdly, under the new system, how will MOE evaluate the performance of the junior colleges?     We should evaluate the teachers on their creativity, not just on the examination results. In a restaurant, if the owner restricts the chef to just a few dishes in the menu, no matter how creative the chef may be, he will not be able to dish out more delicious cuisines to attract more customers. I hope that MOE would also take into consideration the creativity of the teachers when they rank the junior colleges.

Column: 1619



    We should use the 6/2/2 system, that means 60% based on the results attained by the students in the examinations and 20% based on the teaching method of the teachers. We should send out inspectors to schools to evaluate the creative level of the teachers. If the teachers are very creative, we should give them more points, more incentives.
