    Dr John Chen Seow Phun (Hong Kah): Mdm Deputy Speaker, some 13 years ago, when I first entered this reputable Chamber, I commented that our education system produced many students who were "exam-smart", extremely capable of only scoring very many As. I questioned

Column: 1620

then whether this was what our nation wanted to achieve. Now, 13 years on, I am very glad to note that at last the problem is being addressed in a substantial way.

    I agree with many points made in the White Paper. While our system has been efficient in mass producing trained and skilled workers for our early years of industrialisation, it is no longer good enough to take us into the next 30 years in this information era. In this new age, we must be capable of not only producing goods and services, but also new knowledge and intellectual property. Unlike the traditional industrial goods producing economy, the new winners of the information age are companies which own significant IPR like CISCO, Microsoft and Pfizer.

    Are our top students creative enough and enterprising enough to fit into this new era to take Singapore into the brave new world? We must address this problem now. Otherwise, like many other countries, we may get caught in the sandwich class: trapped in between the newly industrialising, low cost countries like China and India, and the western countries who own and produce most of the world's IPR.

    What are the problems we have to address in our education system? Please let me comment on some points from the Report. Firstly, many of our schools and JCs adhere strictly to the syllabus published by the Education Ministry. This leads to a homogenous student population with little variation - hence the lack of diversity. But, parents are also to blame. If you are a bright student scoring many As, try telling your parents that you want to go into drama school to do acting instead of taking up the place offered to you by RJC!

    Secondly, there is an over-emphasis on knowledge per se. Classes become information download sessions. Often neglected are the skills associated with learning, thinking and research. This leads to poor ability to critique, rigidity, poor reasoning skills, low creativity and a spoon-feeding attitude, in which the students (and later our workers) invariably

Column: 1621

await instructions and information from the higher authorities.

    Thirdly, these problems are compounded by "short-termerism", ie, study only for the examinations! Try asking a student something about what he has studied two months after his final 'A' level paper. Or try asking him to read up on something which is interesting but is not in the syllabus. This problem arises from the fact that our examinations are very poorly structured. Questions can be "spotted". Answers are memorised wholesale, sometimes without real understanding of the subject matter. Indeed, even students from our top JCs memorise GP, essays or economic analysis, hoping that their "spotted" topics will "come out" in the final examinations! Is this what we want from our education system?

    In this regard, I must commend CHIJ Katong for being brave enough to make Literature compulsory for their 'O' level students. Literature is sometimes a much dreaded subject. It is difficult to score an A1. There are no good "standard" solutions - no model answers are ever good enough, no DS solution, as we say, in the Army. And everything can be argued from different points of view. Further, it is also very difficult to teach properly because a teacher has to be good enough and confident enough to accommodate many different points of views from the students.

    CHIJ Katong believes that the study of Literature teaches their students life-long skills that will serve them well during their lifetime and it is not for the benefit of scoring A1s during examinations. If the A1s do not materialise, so be it.

    So what are the skill sets which we should try to impart on to our students? There are four basic skill sets which our students should learn by the time they leave the JCs. They are (1) ability to think, reason, self-learn, research for facts, probe by asking intelligent questions and critique. Without this capability, whatever our students learn in their JCs will soon become outdated, if it has not faded from their volatile memory before that. They will certainly not be able to produce new

Column: 1622

knowledge nor lead in any R&D activity. Hence, I would suggest that As and distinctions should not be given for various subjects until a student has clearly demonstrated his thinking and reasoning capability. It is too easy to get an "A" if all it requires is the reproduction of lecture and tutorial notes given by the teachers as model answers. Even a dumb photocopying machine can do this.

    (2) Communications, ie, writing, presentation and recording. As pointed out by the Review Committee, this is a major area of weakness for many of our students. Inventions and discoveries can be useless if nobody understands your achievement. The best business plan will fail from day one if you cannot convince your investor or your potential customers of the superiority of your product. Apart from the formal classroom environment, more student activities like debates, seminars (where the presenters are students themselves), oratorical competition and student workshops should be organised.

    Another important skill which is somewhat lacking is the ability to keep proper (by proper, I mean detailed and precise) records of scientific work. This stems from the over-emphasis of getting the job, such as an experiment, done rather than paying attention to the proper procedures and recording of the conduct of the experiment. Teachers must be also made to realise that laboratory sessions are not only for teaching the basics of the subject matter. They are also to teach students how to conduct and record an investigative procedure in a proper manner. This is an important aspect as R&D activities, especially in the biotech field, will necessitate such skills.

    (3) Teamwork. This has already been addressed in the White Paper. However, I would like to add that students should not be participating in CCA because it is compulsory, or merely for the CCA points which can help in university admission. There is much that can be learnt from being a committee member of a society or representing your school in swimming. Participation should come from interest and enjoyment, not CCA points.

Column: 1623



    (4) Decision making. This point may not have been addressed in detail in the Report. However, it is related, yet different, from the first point on thinking skills. Decision making goes beyond ability to think, reason and fact finding. It involves a certain measure of courage, confidence and leadership. Some will argue that this cannot be formally taught. However, like teamwork skills, we can create the correct environment for students to acquire this ability.

    Let me go through a few other interesting points. The Report suggests "A Broader and More Flexible JC Curriculum". I support increasing the breadth in our education system. However, this should be done through "moral suasion" and education rather than by strict rules. Imposing breadth upon the student's choices may lead to mechanistic rote learning in order to achieve a good result in a subject, taken not because the student loves it, but taken in order to fulfil a government requirement. Is this education? The very thought of imposing such a requirement runs directly counter to the main idea of flexibility. (In a way, diversity also suffers because you are eliminating the possibility of generating some students who would do well in pure Science or pure Arts.)

    I would therefore urge the Education Ministry to consider very carefully how we produce breadth in our JC student's education. Ideally, it should be done by convincing the majority of the students that this will serve them well. It will suffice that a large majority of the students, say, 80% accept this. If the Ministry still decides to impose it as a rule, we should still try to convince the students and their parents of the merits of such a rule. In addition to this, I would urge the Ministry to consider allowing an all-Science (and Mathematics) or an all-Arts option for exceptional cases. In such cases, students may be asked to show that they are highly committed to this very specialised track. This commitment could be shown through, say, doing some of the subjects at the H3 level or special project work.

Column: 1624



    Giving students more flexible options is a good thing. However, many students are not well informed enough to appreciate these options. Their interest in the various subjects has not been fully developed and cultivated. Many make choices due to peer group pressure and by what they hear from the media and their friends.

    Schools should provide better advice and counsel to students making such choices. This should be done on a continuous basis through career talks, visits, career guidance, and other such activities. This process is a long-term one, and should not be done over a short period, just before such choices are made. It is such interest, developed and cultivated over the years, that becomes a passion. Such passion is a seed of possible greater things in the future.

    JCs should be asked to allow more subject combinations. Ideally, students should be given freedom to choose their own subject combinations. This will in turn produce diversity through the diverse subject combinations. Although there may be an administrative and resource problem, we should allow, whenever possible, students to study subjects that they love. I understand from feedback that it is not possible to do "strange" combinations like Literature and Biology. Should this not be allowed?

    I understand that giving absolute freedom of choice may also have its undesirable effects. In our achievement-oriented society, many will go for the combinations that will maximise their chances of getting the most As, rather than taking subjects that interest them. This brings me to the topic of examinations.

    I have touched on the weakness of our examinations earlier. I would like to discuss this in more detail here. While the main examination paper can continue to test for knowledge and standard applications, some questions that test the students' understanding, ability to think and reason, and the ability to draw conclusions in non-standard situations should be included. This is to encourage developing

Column: 1625

knowledge skills, in addition to merely absorbing information.

    I note that certain subjects also produce a disproportionate number of As. The Ministry of Education may want to check this out. Surely, it is possible to equalise this by adjusting the difficulty of level of the examination questions, and by some moderation. We ought to try to remove any incentive for choosing a certain subject due to the ease of getting an A in the examinations.

    Another cause of passive students that we have today is due to our teaching methods. I think there is too much spoon-feeding in our schools and JCs at present. While this may be a very efficient way to scoring high marks in the examinations, it is like a drug. It deadens the mind and the processes of thought, and the student will be nearly all lost once this is removed.

    Next, I would like to touch on the subject of university entrance requirements. I find that the local universities are rather rigid in their methods of selecting students for entry, and for most departments. Generally, points are assigned for various "A" level grades, and these are summed. If you meet the cut-off mark, you are in. Otherwise, you are out. I find this much too clinical. How many points would you give Remy Ong for his three Asian Games Gold medals?

Column: 1626



    A few years back, I appealed on behalf of a national level badminton player for admission to NUS to study engineering. He missed the cut-off mark by one or two points. Column: 1627



    Lastly, I would like to mention that more resources will be needed to truly achieve the goals of this reform. Teachers themselves need to be retrained.     The Minister of State for Defence (Mr Cedric Foo Chee Keng): Mdm Deputy Speaker, I have had the benefit of chairing a sub-committee for Remaking Singapore. We have engaged many people and, from their feedback, I know that Singaporeans take a keen interest in education issues but remain divided about the many features of our education system.

    Today's debate is on a motion of great import. It will determine, in no small part, whether our children will lead fulfilling lives. Once we set our compass and decide on the course, cohorts of Singaporeans will be headed along this course, and it will take us years to change our bearings or to steer them back. Therefore, I commend the Ministry of Education for subjecting its report to robust debate here,

Column: 1628

and the Party for going a step further, to lift the Whip.

    It is difficult to have a meaningful strategic conversation on education until we settle the score on the merits of the different approaches to education. There are, I think, two basic approaches to education. Let us call the first approach the `syllabus-centred' approach, and the second the `learner-centred' approach.

    The first and more traditional syllabus-centred approach in education defines the purpose of teaching as ensuring that students acquire a prescribed body of knowledge and a set of values as determined by society. This is so that they will grow up to meet the needs of the future society, namely, what is required of our citizens and what is required of our workforce.

    What follows from such an approach are didactic teachers, top-down teaching, well-behaved learners, a carefully designed curriculum and a very disciplined environment. The characteristics of such a syllabus-centred approach are sequential preparation for the next educational level, tests at the end of each stage, grouping learners of similar abilities (or streaming), and competition among students and among schools, so as to boost performance.

    The second approach is what we may term as the learner-centred approach. Here, the starting point is the learner, the student or the child, rather than a prescribed body of knowledge. The attributes of this approach are different. Here, a 12-year-old is seen as a 12-year-old, and is to be developed to his or her full potential. The 12-year-olds are not seen as future 13-year-olds and to be prepared as such. The curriculum takes on an open-ended and enquiry-based orientation, and they are taught experientially and through activities, and not taught facts just to be stored. The values to be inculcated are not made to conform to a certain mould that society has pre-determined. Every child is accepted. In fact, every child is celebrated for who he or she is. The role of teachers here is merely to facilitate and ensure that the lid to the brain remains open and not

Column: 1629

to attempt to fill it up. Cooperation, as an underlying social trait, is emphasised over competition.

    Mdm Deputy Speaker, let us consider each of these approaches and see if we can determine the right approach for our time and place.

    The strongest critic of the syllabus-centred approach can be traced back to Charles Dickens. In his novel Hard Times, he said that children subject to such an education system are like "little vessels arranged in order, ready to have imperial gallons of facts poured into them until they are full to the brim." This system requires precise recall of the lessons learnt, great reliance on memorisation - often without actively engaging the student in the learning process. The assumption that knowledge is static, something that already exists, runs counter to the bewildering pace at which knowledge is constantly being reshaped.

    However, there are also proponents of the syllabus-based system, and they have also argued, equally passionately, about the merits of such an approach.     17. Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan asked the Minister for Education (a) what is the number and percentage of children entering primary 1 each year who are identified for the Learning Support Programme (LSP) since the Programme was introduced; (b) how are these children assessed to determine if they need to attend the Programme; (c) what is the standard against which the primary 1 children's reading abilities are benchmarked to determine if they need to attend the Programme; (d) what is the duration of the Programme and; (e) how effective has the Programme been.

    RAdm Teo Chee Hean:

    The Learning Support Programme (LSP) (English) is an early intervention language and literacy programme. The programme was started in 1992 and implemented in all primary schools in 1998. The need for this programme arises out of the complex home language background of our students, resulting in their entering Primary 1 with very different levels of literacy skills in English. The programme provides additional support to pupils in P1 and P2 who do not have the pre-requisite English Language and literacy skills to access the curriculum. Pupils in the LSP are identified through a screening test administered to all P1 pupils at the beginning of the school year. Each year, about 12% to 14% of P1 pupils, or some 7,000 pupils, are supported in the LSP.

    The effectiveness of the programme is measured through gains in children's reading levels and performance in school-based assessments. P1 LSP pupils start school reading at levels equivalent to children of less than 5 years of age, on average. After about 10 months of intervention in the LSP, the average reading age of LSP pupils is 7 years, reflecting a reading gain of 28 months. They are thus comparable with the P1 cohort in terms of their reading levels.

    Improvements in reading have helped the pupils do better in their English tests. For example, in 2001, less than half (45%) of P1 LSP pupils passed English at the mid-year Semestral Assessment (SA1). By SA2 in November, the pass rate was 64.9%.

    The duration of the Learning Support Programme is 2 years. At the end of P2, a small proportion of LSP pupils (about 15% of those originally identified at P1) continue to have difficulties in the English Language. Schools will determine the most appropriate mode of support for these pupils after the 2 years in the LSP programme. These pupils are put through customised remediation programmes conducted by the school, or the ENABLE (ENcouraging Achievement and Better LEarning), a specialised intervention programme in English and Mathematics for pupils who are underachieving.
